newsitem.title: FRANCE: French minister backs suspended policeman.
newsitem.headline: French minister backs suspended policeman.

text.p: The head of the Paris crime squad keeps his job in spite of a court order suspending him from investigative duties, defiant Justice Minister Jacques Toubon told the National Assembly on Tuesday.
Senior policeman Olivier Foll was barred from his main role for six months on Monday for refusing to help a corruption probe into the ruling Gaullist party.
Rejecting opposition charges that he was in contempt of court, Toubon said the court had suspended Foll from his investigative duties, but not from administrative functions.
"The Interior Minister has full power to appoint his staff. The ruling covers Foll's work but and in no way his job," he said.
"Can court rulings be flouted when they do not please the Interior Minister?" a Socialist parliamentarian asked him.
Interior Ministry sources said Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre, who is close to Gaullist President Jacques Chirac, had no intention of sacking Foll after Monday's ruling.
Official sources said Foll could carry on as head of the Criminal Investigation Division but he would have to delegate investigative duties to subordinates.
The court punished Foll for refusing to let his men help investigating judge Eric Halphen search the home of Paris mayor Jean Tiberi in a July probe into Gaullist party fundraising.
Halphen, who was investigating allegations that the Gaullists received kickbacks on housing contracts in the Paris area, had to search Tiberi's home on his own.
Foll, who is appealing the suspension, has complained through his lawyer that Halphen only told the policemen when they got to Tiberi's door whose home they were going to search.

French media say the investigating judge feared police officers assigned to help him were in fact spying for their superiors and trying to delay a probe getting uncomfortably close to Chirac, who was mayor of Paris until elected president last year.
Gaullist Senator Hubert Haenel said the court had rightfully reminded police officers that they had to obey judges and had no business passing judgement on their decisions.
But the court ruling triggered an outcry from police and right-wing magistrates, while the government's stand angered the opposition and left-leaning judges.
"The government must choose: either it protects its friends, or it guarantees the independence of justice," Socialist Party spokesman Francois Hollande told the daily Le Monde.
Hollande and the moderate Magistrates Union said the court, by punishing Foll, had indirectly pointed the finger at Debre who had publicly backed his subordinate.
Senior police officers who were present in court said the punishment was too harsh -- a criticism also voiced by the right-wing Professional Magistrates Association.
